item.title: Personality Quiz
item.description:
The input is a file, filled with pairs of strings.
<X> <name 1> <answers 1> <name 2> <answers 2> ... <name X> <answers X> Copy
There are two ways we can approach this, either implicitly identifying the name, then keep an alternating switch to watch, or an explicit approach.

The implicit flip-flop isn't robust to random newlines
We know that the answers line has a certain character length, uninterrupted by spaces. That can be an identifying factor
corresponds to the number of strings we're anticipating.
Possible answers are , which then get categorized as being on one side or the other of a dimension.

When it comes to actually characterizing their answers, we know that each category has a question it maps too. We simply need to keep count of for each dimension what their percentage is, and their final output. Since we have access to an array, it would be nice to use it to keep track of which questions map to what.
Extrovert / Introvert - (questions 1, 8, 15, 22, etc) Sensation / iNtuition -  (questions 2, 3, 9, 10, 16, 17, 23, 24, etc) Thinking / Feeling - (questions 4, 5, 11, 12, 18, 19, 25, 26, etc) Judging / Perceiving - (questions 6, 7, 13, 14, 20, 21, 27, 28, etc) Copy
Those lists are just constant, and then the results get printed as we go, since each newline isn't contingent on the previous.
We want line based processing to ID when we get new data and it's label, then token-based-processing to split up the answers from the string.
